skills.name: Describe a reflection in a horizontal line by giving the line of reflection as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
Describe a reflection in a vertical line by giving the line of reflection as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object
Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors
Identify that a shape has been translated
Identify that a shape has been rotated

explanations.A: This would be the last transformation, the question is asking about the first - from A to B...
explanations.B: B to C is a reflection. The question is asking about the transformation from A to B...
explanations.C: The shapes are the same size, so it's not dilation. How has A been transformed to get B?
explanations.D: To transform A to B, it has been moved 7 units down. We call this transformation a translation!

explanations.A: The shapes are the same size, so it's not dilation. How has C been transformed to get D?
explanations.B: To transform C to D, it has been moved 2 units left and 7 units up. We call this transformation a translation!
explanations.C: B to C is a reflection. The question is asking about the transformation from C to D...
explanations.D: The shapes have the same orientation, so it's not a rotation... How has C been transformed to get D?

explanations.A: To get from J to K we rotate 90 degrees clockwise about the origin, so this transformation is a rotation!
explanations.B: J to I is a reflection. The question is asking about the transformation from J to K...
explanations.C: The shapes are the same size, so it's not dilation. How has J been transformed to get K?
explanations.D: This would be the first transformation. The question is asking about the last - from J to K...

explanations.A: K to J is a reflection. The question is asking about the transformation from H to I...
explanations.B: H to K is a translation. The question is asking about the transformation from H to I...
explanations.C: To get from H to I we rotate 90 degrees clockwise about the point (3, 0), so this transformation is a rotation!
explanations.D: The shapes are the same size, so it's not dilation. How has H been transformed to get I?

explanations.A: Although this could be a reflection, it wouldn't be in the 洧논-axis. Has K been translated or rotated to get L?
explanations.B: This would be J to K... The question is asking about K to L
explanations.C: To transform K to L, it has been moved 4 units left. We call this transformation a translation!
explanations.D: This would be J to L, but the question is asking about K to L

explanations.A: This would be the last transformation, the question is asking about the first - from J to K...
explanations.B: Although this could be a reflection, it wouldn't be in the 洧논-axis. Has J been translated or rotated to get K?
explanations.C: So close... Make sure you're going from a corner on J to the same corner on K!
explanations.D: To transform J to K, it has been moved 6 units right. We call this transformation a translation!

explanations.A: Looking at the diagram, we can see X is 3 spaces away from the 洧녽-axis and so is Y (in the opposite direction). Therefore, this transformation is a reflection in the 洧녽-axis!
explanations.B: This would be the last transformation. The question is asking about the first - from X to Y...
explanations.C: One corner has been translated, but for it to be a translation every corner needs to be translated... Has X been reflected or rotated to get Y?
explanations.D: This would be the last transformation. The question is asking about the first - from X to Y...

explanations.A: This would be the first transformation, the question is asking about the last - from Y to Z...
explanations.B: Looking at the diagram, we can see Y is 3 spaces away from the 洧녽-axis and so is Z (in the opposite direction). Therefore, this transformation is a reflection in the 洧녽-axis!
explanations.C: Although rotating Y 90 degrees clockwise would give the correct orientation of Z, the center of rotation given is not correct... Has Y been reflected or translated to get Z?
explanations.D: So close... Double check which axis you're reflecting in!

explanations.A: So close... Double check which axis you're reflecting in!
explanations.B: Make sure you're looking at the right shapes... The third transformation is from V to W
explanations.C: Looking at the diagram, we can see V is 1 space away from the 洧논-axis and so is W (in the opposite direction). Therefore, this transformation is a reflection in the 洧논-axis!
explanations.D: This would be the transformation from U to V... The question is asking about V to W!

explanations.A: Make sure you're looking at the right shapes... The second transformation is from U to V
explanations.B: So close... Double check which axis you're reflecting in!
explanations.C: This would be the transformation from T to U... The question is asking about U to V!
explanations.D: Looking at the diagram, we can see U is 2 spaces away from the 洧논-axis and so is V (in the opposite direction). Therefore, this transformation is a reflection in the 洧논-axis!
